{{for|the Anglican vicar|Albert James Adams}} {{Infobox person | name = Albert J. Adams | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = May 22, 1845 | birth_place = [[Blackstone, Massachusetts]] | death_date = October 1, 1906 (aged 61) | death_place = [[Ansonia Hotel]], New York | occupation = [[Numbers game]] | death_cause = [[Suicide]] | parents = | children = }}
'''Albert James Adams''' (May 22, 1845 – October 1, 1906), known as "The Policy King" and the "Meanest Man in New York," was an American racketeer. He ran the [[numbers game]] in [[New York City]] from around 1890 to around 1905.
==Life== He was born in [[Massachusetts]] and lived in [[Rhode Island]] before he moved to [[New York City]] in 1871 as a brakeman for the railroad. He married Isabella (1840-?) and had six children: Albert J. Adams, Jr. (1870-?); Lawrence Adams (1874-?); Louis Adams (1875-?); Walter C. Adams (1877-?); Evelyn Adams (1879-?) aka Eveline Adams, who married a Napoleon; and Ida Adams (1874-?) or Claudia P. Adams. In 1880 he was living at 236 West 38th Street in Manhattan and he listed himself as a "segar dealer".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Image:1880_census_Adams.jpg |title=Albert J. Adams in the 1880 US Census in Manhattan |accessdate=2008-07-23 |quote= |publisher=[[1880 US Census]] }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Image:1900_census_Adams.jpg |title=Albert J. Adams in the 1900 US Census in Manhattan |accessdate=2008-07-23 |quote= |publisher=[[1900 US Census]] }}</ref>
He was named by the [[Lexow Committee]], and was replaced by [[Peter H. Matthews]] when he retired. The anonymous testifier at the Lexow Committee in 1894 said: "[the principal policy backers in this city are] Al Adams. 'Jake' Shipsey, [[Cornelius B. Parker]], 'Billy' Myers, 'Ed' Hogan, [and] [[Charles Frederick Lindauer|Charles Lindauer]]. ...Al has the most ... sheets, and he is the biggest man, and has the most money, and has the biggest pile. ... He is called the king of the policy dealers. ... Al Adams has from Fourteenth street up on the west side mostly." After a 1901 raid on his gambling operation by [[F. Norton Goddard]], the police estimated that he was making more than $1 million a year, and after his conviction in 1903 it was revealed that he had been allowed to stay at the [[Waldorf-Astoria]] until he was sentenced. He was sentenced on April 21, 1903, to "not less than a year and not more than one year and nine months" in [[Sing-Sing]].
On April 5, 1904, his application for [[parole]] was denied by the [[New York State Board of Parole]]. The board members being [[C. V. Collins]], the [[Superintendent of Prisons]]; State Treasurer [[John G. Wickser]] and president of the [[New York State Prison Commission]] [[John P. Jaeckel]]. This meant he was to stay in prison for the maximum time of the sentence.<ref>{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=No Parole for "Al" Adams. State Board Decides Against ex-Policy King's Application. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1904/04/06/100467964.pdf |quote=The Board of Parole to-day denied the application of ... |work=The New York Times |date=April 6, 1904 |accessdate=2008-07-23 | format=PDF}}</ref>
On October 8, 1905, he wrote to ''[[The New York Times]]'' that he had quit the [[policy racket]] forever.<ref>{{cite news |first=Adams |last=Albert |authorlink= |coauthors= |title="Al" Adams Has Quit. Says He's Dropped Policy Forever and Would Forget Past Troubles. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1905/10/08/101707738.pdf |quote=To the editor of ''The New York Times'': My attention has been called to the fact that my name has been extensively coupled with the recent policy raids in Brooklyn. I wish to ask your indulgence in denying the truth of such allegations. Let me say once and for all time, I am absolutely and forever out of politics, gambling policy and all kinds of lotteries. |work=The New York Times |date=October 8, 1905 |accessdate=2008-07-23 | format=PDF}}</ref>
He committed suicide at the [[Ansonia Hotel]] in 1906 after losing several million dollars by investing in a business venture with his eldest son. The funeral was held at 471 West End, he was 61 years old.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nyc-architecture.com/ARCH/ARCH-McKimMeadandWhite.htm |title=McKim, Mead, and White |accessdate=2008-07-23 |quote=The Billsons soon left, for in October 1906 the house was the scene of the funeral of Albert J. Adams, who had committed suicide at the Ansonia Hotel at Broadway and 73rd Street. The New York Times said that Adams, who had been living at No. 471, was ''better known as Al Adams, the Policy King.'' |publisher=New York City Architecture }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title="Al" Adams a Suicide, Following Misfortunes; Broken By Ill-health and Money Losses, He Shoots Himself. Sage & Co. Sank $2,000,000. He Also Felt Deeply The Disgrace Of Prison Sentence. Great Fortune Made In Policy Swindle. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1906/10/02/101831506.pdf |quote="Al" Adams, known as the "Policy King," committed suicide yesterday morning by shooting himself. Members of his family and those in the apartment house who ... Standing before a mirror in his apartment on the fifteenth floor of the Ansonia apartment hotel, "Al" Adams, known as the "Policy King," committed suicide ... |work=The New York Times |date=October 2, 1906 |accessdate=2008-07-23 | format=PDF}}</ref> His death did not end the [[policy racket]] in [[New York City]].<ref>{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Policy Ring Chiefs Confess to Judge. "Al" Adams's Successors Say Their Capture Frees New York of That Evil. Tell of $200 A Day Profits. Three Leaders Expect Light Sentences Because of Frankness in Revelations.|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1915/12/02/104658612.pdf |quote=Three of four men who pleaded guilty to policy playing before Justice Weeks in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court yesterday were leaders in what has been called the only policy ring able to thrive here since the collapse of "Al" Adams's regime. From the remnants of Adams's operations they developed a syndicate with wide ramifications, which yesterday's procedure, according to Justice Weeks's own statement, completely wiped out of existence.|work=The New York Times |date=December 2, 1915 |accessdate=2008-07-23 | format=PDF}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{wikisource}} *{{findagrave|74653526}} *[http://richard.arthur.norton.googlepages.com/albertadamsbibliography Albert J. Adams bibliography] *[http://www.hti.umich.edu/cgi/t/text/pageviewer-idx?c=moa;cc=moa;g=moagrp;xc=1;sid=29604fe5d00bc2e666e7c1e6d9a7c16c;q1=lindauer;rgn=full%20text;idno=AAW4711.0003.001;view=image;seq=00000784 Lexow Committee Transcript; 1894]
{{s-start}} {{succession box | before=[[Zachariah Simmons]] | title=[[Policy racket]] in [[New York City]] | years=c. 1890–1905 | after=[[Peter H. Matthews]]}} {{s-end}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Adams, Albert J.}} [[Category:1845 births]] [[Category:1906 deaths]] [[Category:Numbers game]] [[Category:Criminals from New York City]] [[Category:Criminals who committed suicide]] [[Category:Sing Sing]] [[Category:Suicides in New York (state)]] [[Category:People from Blackstone, Massachusetts]]

{{Infobox musical artist | name = Alexandra Govere | birth_name = Alexandra Shungudzo Govere | image = GovereBeach.png | caption = Alexandra Govere performing on a public beach in Malibu, California. | image_size = | background = solo_singer | origin = [[Bikita]], [[Zimbabwe]] | genre = [[Pop music|pop]], [[folk music]] | occupation = [[philanthropist]], [[singer]], [[songwriter]], [[record producer]] | years_active = 2010–present | label = Independent | associated_acts = [[Kerry Brothers, Jr.]] }} '''Alexandra Govere''' is an American [[philanthropist]], [[singer]], [[songwriter]], [[record producer]], [[gymnast]], [[journalist]] and [[reality television]] personality. She first attracted media attention by being the first black female gymnast to represent Zimbabwe in artistic gymnastics at the [[1999 All-Africa Games]], and later by co-founding the Kijana Project, which provides relief for AIDS orphans. She later gained wide media attention as a cast member on the 2011 season of ''[[The Real World: San Diego (2011)|The Real World: San Diego]]''. ==Early life == Alexandra Govere was born in the United States but grew up in [[Zimbabwe]], in a rural village that was home to straw-covered mud huts, and did not have electricity or running water.Goldner, Brandon. [http://www.brassmagazine.com/article/sing-dance-write-andra-govere-most-amazing-20-something-you-havent-heard-yet… "Sing. Dance. Write. Andra Govere: The most amazing 20-something you haven't heard of. Yet…"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180612162409/http://www.brassmagazine.com/article/sing-dance-write-andra-govere-most-amazing-20-something-you-havent-heard-yet%25E2%2580%25A6# |date=2018-06-12 }}. ''Brass'' magazine. May 2, 2011 She is of [[Zimbabwean]], [[French people|French]], and [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Amerindian]] descent. Her family eventually relocated to California,[http://vevmo.com/f256/the-real-world-san-diego-la-5895/ "Real World: San Diego: La Jolla (2011) - Alexandra Govere] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110918110620/http://vevmo.com/f256/the-real-world-san-diego-la-5895/ |date=2011-09-18 }} Vevmo, August 4, 2011 and as of the early 2000s, she was living in [[Oregon]].[http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qa3812/is_200005/ai_n8894229/?tag=mantle_skin;content "Ready for their world: Two teens with the right stuff join the global party"]. [[BNET]].{{deadlink|date=June 2018}} ==Career== ===Ballet, gymnastics and education=== Govere practiced dancing and ballet, and according to her, became the first female of color to be on the Zimbabwe National Gymnastics Team at age 9. Her parents, both of whom are college graduates, encouraged her in her studies as well. She studied calculus at age 10, and finished high school by 14. She later attended [[Stanford University]], where she studied civil engineering.[http://www.mtv.com/shows/real_world/san_diego/cast_member.jhtml?personalityId=15044#moreinfo Real World: San Diego: Cast: Alexandra]. MTV. accessed September 30, 2011.Note: Sources conflict on whether she graduated. The [http://www.brassmagazine.com/article/sing-dance-write-andra-govere-most-amazing-20-something-you-havent-heard-yet… ''Brass'' article] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180612162409/http://www.brassmagazine.com/article/sing-dance-write-andra-govere-most-amazing-20-something-you-havent-heard-yet%25E2%2580%25A6# |date=2018-06-12 }} indicates she graduated with a civil engineering degree, though her [http://www.mtv.com/shows/real_world/san_diego/cast_member.jhtml?personalityId=15044#moreinfo MTV.com bio] indicates she dropped out eight weeks prior to graduation. Govere was the first black female artistic gymnast to represent Zimbabwe at the [[1999 All-Africa Games]] in [[Johannesburg]].[http://www.thezimbabwean.co.uk/entertainment/music-and-dance/33117/zim-songstress-causes-a-stir.html "Zim songstress causes a stir"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110923094616/http://www.thezimbabwean.co.uk/entertainment/music-and-dance/33117/zim-songstress-causes-a-stir.html |date=2011-09-23 }}. ''The Zimbabwean''. July 30, 2010. retrieved September 27, 2011.Johnson, Steve. [http://allafrica.com/stories/199910250173.html "Zimbabwean Gymnast Makes History"]. [[AllAfrica]].com. October 25, 1999 She was also the youngest member of the 162-member team. ===Charity work=== In 1997, Govere began collecting clothing for orphans who lost their parents to AIDS.{{Cite web|url=http://web.archive.org/web/20110929000145/http://voice.paly.net/node/13599|title=GovereÃ‚â€™s worldwide program continues to assist AIDS orphans {{!}} The Paly Voice|date=2011-09-29|access-date=2018-08-27}} By 2002, the Kijana Project,Olson, Linnea. [https://books.google.com/books?id=PiUEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA141&dq=alexandra+govere&hl=en&ei=0X3yTY74JIbCsAP94JnbCw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CD8Q6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=alexandra%20govere&f=false "The Kids Are Alright"]. ''[[Elle Girl]]'' Sep-Oct 2003. page 141. [[Google Books]]. accessed August 4, 2011. as it came to be called, had expanded to an international organization run by then-15-year-old Govere and her sister Saunsuray, consisting of 50 members who aided orphans in six different countries, raising money for clothing, toys and school supplies, as well as paying for the education of some AIDS orphans. Govere was spurred to this work after witnessing many of her childhood classmates affected by AIDS, and seeing the rising number of orphans living on the streets of Harare. In 2000, she worked with her sister in collecting money for Red Cross flood relief in Mozambique.{{Cite journal|date=2018-04-03|title=2000 Mozambique flood|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=2000_Mozambique_flood&oldid=834046330|journal=Wikipedia|language=en}} For breaking the color barrier in artistic gymnastics, and for her humanitarian work, Govere was designated a Disney-UNESCO Millennium Dreamers Ambassador.{{Cite web|url=http://www.un.org/press/en/2000/20000320.note5604.doc.html|title=NOTE TO CORRESPONDENTS "MILLENNIUM DREAMERS" DELEGATES TO BE ANNOUNCED|last=United Nations|first=|date=20 March 2000|website=United Nations|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} ===Music and television=== While attending Stanford University, Govere was discovered by [[Alicia Keys]]' Grammy Award-winning producer, Kerry "Krucial" Brothers, who had heard some songs Govere placed on [[MySpace]] for her mother to hear. Although she initially met with Brothers with the intent to be a songwriter, he made her sing vocals, and recognized her talent. With him, she released a mixtape, "[[Love is 4 Suckaz/I'm a Sucka 4 Love]]", some songs from which are available on [[YouTube]]. ''Brass'' magazine describes the mixtape as "a high-wattage soup of synthetic beats and heavy post-production mixing", whose lyrics focus on the themes of love, jealousy, revenge and anti-consumerism. Describing Govere's voice, Brandon Goldner of ''Brass'' says, "[Her voice] can range from bright and flute-like to a rougher, almost smoky honesty" Although Govere planned to debut a 2011 album with Krucial,[http://pumpthebeat.com/?p=1950 "Album: "Love is 4 Suckaz / I'm A Sucka 4 Love" by Andra"]. August 14, 2010[http://dubstepsource.com/andra-ft-lupe-fiasco-white-swans-2/ "Andra ft. Lupe Fiasco – White Swans"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110815074012/http://dubstepsource.com/andra-ft-lupe-fiasco-white-swans-2/ |date=2011-08-15 }}. Dubstep Source. July 6, 2010 She announced in October 2011 that she left Krucial in order to take the independent route.Govere, Alexandra.[http://toosweettobebitter.tumblr.com/post/11146820788/music-things "Music & Things"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425051706/http://toosweettobebitter.tumblr.com/post/11146820788/music-things |date=2012-04-25 }}. Too Sweet To Be Bitter. October 7, 2011Govere, Alexandra. [https://www.facebook.com/topic.php?topic=759&uid=130231877017340, "Music & Things"]. [[Facebook]]. October 7, 2011 She has co-written a number of hit songs such as Little Mix's "Touch" and Louisa Johnson's “Best Behaviour,”{{Cite web|url=http://bigdealmusic.com/artists/shungudzo/|title=Shungudzo|last=Big Deal Music|first=|date=2018|website=Big DEal Music|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} and has recently released a song on the Fifty Shades Freed soundtrack.{{Cite web|url=https://hamadamania.com/2018/02/10/shungudzo-unleashes-new-promotional-single-come-on-back/|title=Shungudzo unleashes new promotional single 'Come On Back'|last=Hamada Mania Music|first=|date=|website=Hamada Mania Music|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} Govere was a cast member on [[MTV]]'s ''[[The Real World: San Diego (2011)|The Real World: San Diego]]'', which aired from September to December 2011. Govere was a writer, host, and correspondent for both [[MTV]] Act and MTV Voices.[http://act.mtv.com/posts/author/goverea/ "Alexandra Govere"]. MTV Act Blog. Retrieved May 19, 2012.[http://voices.mtv.co.uk/author/alexandra-govere/ "Alexandra Govere"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120507013733/http://voices.mtv.co.uk/author/alexandra-govere/# |date=2012-05-07 }}. MTV Voices UK. Retrieved May 19, 2012. ==Personal life== As of 2011, Govere was living in [[Los Angeles]] with her boyfriend, Byron, whom she began seeing eight months prior to filming ''The Real World''.{{Cite web|url=http://web.archive.org/web/20120624043800/http://www.mtv.com/videos/real-world-san-diego-ep-1-first-impressions/1671710/playlist.jhtml|title=Real World San Diego {{!}} Ep. 1 {{!}} First Impressions {{!}} MTV|date=2012-06-24|access-date=2018-08-27}} Their relationship was depicted in episode 4 of [[The Real World: San Diego (2011)|that season]] when he visited her at the season residence.{{Cite web|url=http://web.archive.org/web/20121122110207/http://www.mtv.com/videos/real-world-san-diego-ep-4-hair-razing-arguments-and-sticky-situations/1672818/playlist.jhtml|title=Real World San Diego {{!}} Ep. 4 {{!}} Hair-Razing Arguments And Sticky Situations {{!}} MTV|date=2012-11-22|access-date=2018-08-27}} ==Discography== ===Singles=== ====as lead artist==== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! scope="col" style="width:160px;"| Title ! scope="col" | Year ! scope="col" style="width:180px;"| Album |- ! scope="row"| "Long Live the Billionaire" | 2017 | rowspan="2" {{n/a|Non-album single}} |- ! scope="row"| "Paper" | 2018 |- |} ====as featured artist==== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! scope="col" style="width:160px;"| Title ! scope="col" | Year ! scope="col" style="width:180px;"| Album |- ! scope="row"| "Roll with Me"
{{small|(Bantu featuring Shungudzo)}} | rowspan="2"| 2017 | {{n/a|Non-album single}} |- ! scope="row"| "Bicycle"

{{small|([[Oliver Heldens]] featuring Shungudzo)}} | {{n/a|Non-album single}} |- |} ===Guest appearances=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |+ List of non-single guest appearances, with other performing artists, showing year released and album name ! scope="col" style="width:20em;"| Title ! scope="col"| Year ! scope="col"| Other artist(s) ! scope="col"| Album |- ! scope="row"| "Complicated" | rowspan="2"| 2017 | Bantu | ''Africa for the Summer EP'' |- ! scope="row"| "Ougadougou" | BC Unidos | ''Bicycle EP'' |- ! scope="row"| "Come on Back" | 2018 | Shungudzo | ''[[Fifty Shades Freed (film)|Fifty Shades Freed: Original Motion Picture Soundtrack]]'' |- |} ===Songwriting credits=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! scope="col" style="width:160px;"| Title ! scope="col" | Year ! scope="col" | Artist(s) ! scope="col" style="width:180px;"| Album ! scope="col" | Written with |- ! scope="row"| "[[Touch (Little Mix song)|Touch]]" | 2016 | [[Little Mix]] | ''[[Glory Days (Little Mix album)|Glory Days]]'' | Hanni Ibrahim, Patrick Patrikios, Philip Plested |- ! scope="row"| "Not That Girl" | rowspan="6"| 2017 | [[Girli]] | ''Feel Ok EP'' | [[Girli|Milly Toomey]] |- ! scope="row"| "[[Best Behaviour (Louisa Johnson song)|Best Behaviour]]" | [[Louisa Johnson|Louisa]] | {{n/a|Non-album single}} | [[TMS (production team)|Thomas Barnes]], [[TMS (production team)|Peter Kelleher]], [[TMS (production team)|Benjamin Kohn]], [[Danny Parker (songwriter)|Daniel Parker]] |- ! scope="row"| "It Won't Kill Ya"

scope="row"| "Your Domino" | [[Jessie Ware|Jessica Ware]], [[Stint (producer)|Ajay Bhattacharya]], [[Danny Parker (songwriter)|Daniel Parker]], Daniel Sinclair |- ! scope="row"| "Love to Love" | [[Jessie Ware|Jessica Ware]], [[Stint (producer)|Ajay Bhattacharya]], [[Danny Parker (songwriter)|Daniel Parker]] |- ! scope="row"| "Wish I Never Met You" | rowspan="6"| 2018 | [[Victoria Monét]] | ''Life After Love, Pt 1'' | [[Victoria Monét|Victoria McCants]], [[Verse Simmonds|Maurice "Verse" Simmonds]] |- ! scope="row"| "Way Down" | [[MØ]] | ''[[Forever Neverland]]'' | [[MØ|Karen Marie Ørsted]], [[Stint (producer)|Ajay Bhattacharya]], Letter Mbulu, Caiphus Semenya |- ! scope="row"| "Wasabi" | [[Little Mix|Jade Thirwall]], [[MNEK|Uzoechi Emenike]], Mike Sabath |- ! scope="row"| "Notice" | [[Little Mix|Leigh-Anne Pinnock]], [[Little Mix|Jade Thirwall]], Mike Sabath |- |} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Govere, Alexandra}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:HIV/AIDS activists]] [[Category:Zimbabwean female artistic gymnasts]] [[Category:The Real World cast members]] [[Category:Zimbabwean emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:Sportspeople from Masvingo Province]]

revision.text:
{{mergefrom|Lisa Ann Millican|date=October 2018}}{{Infobox murderer | name = Alvin Neelley | alias = | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = Alvin Howard Neelley, Jr. | birth_date = {{Birth date|1953|07|15}} | birth_place = [[Trion, Georgia]], [[United States|U.S.]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|2005|10|21|1953|07|15}} | death_place = [[Milledgeville, Georgia|Milledgeville]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], U.S. | cause = [[Complication (medicine)|Surgical complication]] | victims = 2 | beginyear = 1982 | endyear = 1982 | country = United States | states = Georgia | apprehended = October 14, 1982 | conviction = [[murder]] and [[aggravated assault]] | sentence = [[Life imprisonment in the United States|Life imprisonment]] | imprisoned = [[Bostick State Prison]], [[Hardwick, Baldwin County, Georgia|Hardwick, Georgia]] | spouse = {{marriage|Judith Neelley|1980|2005|end=his death}} | children = 3 | height = | weight = }} {{Infobox murderer | name = Judith Neelley | alias = | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = Judith Ann Adams | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1964|06|07}} | birth_place = [[Murfreesboro, Tennessee|Murfeesboro]], [[Tennessee]], U.S. | death_date = | death_place = | cause = | victims = 2 | beginyear = 1982 | endyear = 1982 | country = United States | states = Georgia | apprehended = October 9, 1982 | conviction = [[murder]] | sentence = [[Capital punishment in the United States|Death]] commuted to [[Life imprisonment in the United States|life in prison]] | imprisoned = [[Julia Tutwiler Prison for Women]], [[Wetumpka, Alabama|Wetumpka]], [[Alabama]] | spouse = {{marriage|Alvin Neelley|1980|2005|end=his death}} | children = 3 | height = | weight = }}'''Alvin Howard Neelley, Jr.''' (July 15, 1953 – October 21, 2005) and '''Judith Ann Adams Neelley''' (born June 7, 1964) are an [[United States|American]] couple who committed the [[kidnapping]]s and [[torture murder]]s of [[Lisa Ann Millican]] and Janice Kay Chatman; they also attempted a third abduction. Judith was [[sentenced to death]] in 1983, but her sentence was [[commutation of sentence|commuted]] to [[life imprisonment]] in 1999.<ref name="Alvin Death">{{cite news |url=http://www.chattanoogan.com/articles/article_74677.asp |title=Alvin Neelley Dies In Prison |accessdate=2013-05-28}}</ref> She is serving her sentence at the [[Julia Tutwiler Prison for Women]] in [[Wetumpka, Alabama|Wetumpka]], [[Alabama]].<ref name="Judy Prison">{{cite news |url=http://doc.state.al.us/inmresults.asp?AIS=&FirstName=j&LastName=neelley |title=Inmate Search Results |deadurl=yes |accessdate=2013-05-28 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120331002005/http://doc.state.al.us/inmresults.asp?AIS=&FirstName=j&LastName=neelley |archive-date=2012-03-31 |df= }}</ref> Alvin was serving a life sentence at the [[Bostick State Prison]] in [[Hardwick, Baldwin County, Georgia|Hardwick]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] at the time of his death in 2005.<ref name="Alvin Death"/>
==Early lives== ===Alvin Neelley=== Alvin Howard Neelley, Jr., was born in 1953 in [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], where he was a [[car thief]] during his teenage years. He met his second wife, Judith Ann Adams, when he was 26 years old and she was 15. Alvin divorced his first wife shortly before [[eloping]] with Judith in 1980.<ref name="Boney and Claude">{{cite news |url=http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/notorious_murders/women/neelley/5.html |title=Nightrider and Lady Sundown: The Bonnie and Clyde of Georgia |accessdate=2013-05-28}}</ref>
===Judith Ann Neelley=== Judith Ann Adams was born in [[Murfreesboro, Tennessee|Murfeesboro]], [[Tennessee]], on June 7, 1964. Her father, an [[alcoholic]], died in a motorcycle accident when she was nine. After meeting Neelley, she began her life of crime, committing [[armed robberies|armed robbery]] across the country (even when heavily pregnant) for which she was later caught. She gave birth to [[twins]] while incarcerated at [[Rome, Georgia]]'s Youth Development Center.<ref name="Boney and Claude"/>
==Youth Development Center crimes== On September 11, 1982, Ken Dooley, a Youth Development Center employee, was shot at four times. The following day, fellow employee Linda Adair's home was [[firebombing|firebombed]] with a [[Molotov cocktail]]. Phone calls were made to the victims following the attacks by a female who claimed to have been [[sexual abuse|sexually abused]] at the YDC, but neither victim could identify the caller's voice.<ref name="Judy Neelley">{{cite news |url=http://ourgeorgiahistory.com/ogh/Judy_Neelley_-_A_woman_on_death_row |title=Judy Neelley - A woman on death row |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120301015655/http://ourgeorgiahistory.com/ogh/Judy_Neelley_-_A_woman_on_death_row |archivedate=2012-03-01 |accessdate=2013-05-28}}</ref><ref name="Mysterious Attacks">{{cite news |url=http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/notorious_murders/women/neelley/1.html |title=Nightrider and Lady Sundown: The Bonnie and Clyde of Georgia |accessdate=2013-05-28}}</ref>
==Lisa Ann Millican== [[Lisa Ann Millican]], a 13-year-old girl from [[Cedartown, Georgia]], was abducted by the Neelleys from Rome's [[Riverbend Mall]] on September 25, 1982.<ref name="Judy Neelley"/> She was taken to a motel in [[Scottsboro, Alabama|Scottsboro]], [[Alabama]], where the couple held her captive. During her captivity, Lisa was [[rape]]d by both Neelleys multiple times. On September 28, Judith injected Lisa with [[Drano]], first into one side, and later into both sides of her neck, both arms, and both buttocks in an attempt to poison her to death. [[Liquid Plumber]] was also used on some of the injections. When the painful poisoning failed to kill her, Lisa was shot in the back [[execution-style]] by Judith. Her body thrown over a cliff in the [[Little River Canyon]] in [[Fort Payne, Alabama]].<ref name="Alvin Death"/> Judith later called various police agencies several times to report the location of Lisa's body, where it was found on the canyon floor draped over a fallen tree.<ref name="Serial Killers">{{cite news|url=http://www.skcentral.com/articles.php?article_id=508 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20110928130827/http://www.skcentral.com/articles.php?article_id=508 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2011-09-28 |title=Alvin and Judith Ann Neelley |accessdate=2013-05-28}}</ref>
==Janice Chatman and John Hancock== Janice Chatman and John Hancock were a young engaged couple from Rome. On October 4, 1982, they were abducted by Judith.<ref name="Judy Neelley"/> Hancock was shot while Chatman was abducted and brought back to the Neelleys' motel room, where she was tortured and murdered. Hancock, however, survived the shooting and was able to identify the Neelleys as his assailants.<ref name="Serial Killers"/>
==Arrests and trial== Judith was arrested on October 9, 1982, and Alvin was taken into custody a few days later.<ref name="Judy Neelley"/> Judith was deduced as being the perpetrator in the YDC attacks.<ref name="Serial Killers"/> To avoid the [[death penalty]], Alvin pleaded guilty to [[murder]] and [[aggravated assault]] in Georgia. He was not tried for the Millican murder.<ref name="Serial Killers"/>
Judith's trial began on March 7, 1983, in Fort Payne. Before her trial, however, she gave birth to a third child behind bars.<ref name="Judy Neelley"/> Judith was ultimately convicted of the [[torture murder]] of Lisa Ann Millican. Despite a jury's recommendation to sentence Judith to [[life imprisonment|life in prison]], Judge Randall Cole sentenced the 18-year-old mother of three to death in Alabama's [[electric chair]].<ref name="Judy Pardon">{{cite news |url=http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/notorious_murders/women/neelley/10.html |title=Nightrider and Lady Sundown: The Bonnie and Clyde of Georgia |accessdate=2013-05-28}}</ref> After her conviction, Judith pleaded guilty to Chatman's murder.
==Aftermath== Alvin was incarcerated at the [[Bostick State Prison]] from 1983 until his death in October 2005.<ref name="Alvin Death"/>
At 18-years-old, Judith became the youngest woman [[capital punishment in the United States|sentenced to death]] in the U.S. She was placed on Alabama's [[death row]], at the [[Julia Tutwiler Prison for Women]]. Judith [[appeal]]ed for a [[new trial]], but it was denied in March 1987. In 1989, the [[United States Supreme Court|U.S. Supreme Court]] affirmed her death sentence. On January 15, 1999, Judith was days from her execution date when [[Governor of Alabama|Governor]] [[Fob James]] [[clemency|commuted]] her sentence to life in prison with a possibility of [[parole]] in another 15 years (thus, a minimum of 31 years in prison).<ref name="Judy Pardon"/><ref name="blog.al.com">{{cite news |url=http://blog.al.com/breaking/2009/01/judith_ann_neelley_no_longer_e.html|title=Judith Ann Neelley no longer eligibile for parole |accessdate=2013-05-28}}</ref> The decision was met with controversy, but Gov. James – long known for his "[[Law and order (politics)|tough]]" position on crime – cited the jury's recommendation for Judith's sentencing. Judith would have been eligible for parole in January 2014, at age 49, but the Alabama legislature passed a law in 2003 that made her ineligible.<ref name="Judy Pardon"/><ref name="blog.al.com"/>
==In the media== On February 28, 2008, the Neelleys' case was profiled on the [[Investigation Discovery]] (ID) program ''[[Most Evil]]''. On a scale developed by [[forensic psychiatrist]] Michael Stone, Judith was ranked as a category 22 killer, the "most evil" level deemed for serial torture murderers.<ref name="Most Evil">{{cite news |url=http://investigation.discovery.com/tv/most-evil/ep-guide/most-evil-ep-guide.html |title=Most Evil : Episode Guide : Investigation Discovery |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080222090233/http://investigation.discovery.com/tv/most-evil/ep-guide/most-evil-ep-guide.html |archivedate=2008-02-22 |accessdate=2013-05-28}}</ref> The Neelleys were later featured on the ID programs ''[[Wicked Attraction]]''<ref name="Wicked Attraction">{{cite news |url=http://investigation.discovery.com/tv/wicked-attraction/ |title=Wicked Attraction: Investigation Discovery |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110222031013/http://investigation.discovery.com/tv/wicked-attraction/ |archivedate=2011-02-22 |accessdate=2013-05-28}}</ref> and ''[[Deadly Women]]''.<ref name="Deadly Women">{{cite news|url=http://investigation.discovery.com/tv/deadly-women/ |title=Twisted Thrills |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110815194714/http://investigation.discovery.com/tv/deadly-women/ |archivedate=August 15, 2011 }}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}} {{portal bar|Biography|Criminal Justice|Alabama|Georgia (U.S. state)}}

{{Spanish name|Cabral de Melo|Carbajal}} {{Infobox officeholder |honorific-prefix = |name = Antonio Cabral de Melo y Carbajal |honorific-suffix = |image = |imagesize = |smallimage = |alt = |caption = |order = Accionero del Ganado Vacuno of |office = Buenos Aires Province |term_start = 1678 |term_end = 1717 |monarch = |predecessor = Cristóbal Cabral de Melo |successor = [[Miguel Gerónimo de Esparza]] |birth_date = 1646 |birth_place = [[Buenos Aires]], [[Argentina]] |death_date = c.1717 |death_place = [[Buenos Aires]], [[Argentina]] |restingplace = |restingplacecoordinates = |birthname = Antonio Román Cabral de Melo Alpoim y Carbajal de Salas.{{Citation |last= |first= |year= |title=Revista patriótica del pasado argentino, Volumen 1|publisher=Pedro de Montenegro|publication-place= |page= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AfxaAAAAMAAJ&q=Antonio+Cabral+de+melo+carvajal&dq=Antonio+Cabral+de+melo+carvajal&hl=es&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi0h9OKwprOAhUDE5AKHbmbARUQ6AEIGjAA|accessdate= }} |nationality = Spanish |party = |otherparty = |spouse = Leonor de Morales |partner = |relations = |children = |residence = |alma_mater = |occupation = [[Landowner]]
[[cattle]]
[[merchant]] |profession = [[Militia|Militia Officer]] |cabinet = |committees = |portfolio = |religion = Catholicism |signature =Antonio Cabral de Melo, firma.jpg |signature_alt = |website = |footnotes = |nickname = |allegiance = {{flag|Spanish Empire|name=Spanish Empire}} |branch = Milicias Provinciales de Buenos Aires |serviceyears = |rank = [[Captain]] |unit = |commands = |battles = |awards = }} '''Antonio Cabral de Melo''' (1646-c.1717) was a Spanish landowner and Captain of provincial militias.{{Citation |last= |first= |year= |title=Historia de Zárate, 1689-1909|publisher=by Vicente Raúl Botta|publication-place= |page= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kuSfAAAAMAAJ&q=antonio+cabral+caravajal&dq=antonio+cabral+caravajal&hl=es&sa=X&ei=dVllVNn2C_GZsQTUoILICQ&ved=0CCcQ6AEwAg|accessdate= }} He dedicated himself to the raising of cattle and agriculture, later obtaining the position of ''Accionero'' ([[:es:Vaquería (caza)|Vaquería (caza)]]) of the [[Río de la Plata]], with permission for the slaughter of the cattle cimarron.{{Citation |last= |first= |year= |title=Acuerdos del extinguido Cabildo de Buenos Aires (1719-1721)|publisher=Archivo General de la Nación|publication-place= |page= |url=http://dgcultura.legislatura.gov.ar/cgi-bin/pgopac.cgi?VDOC=1.15552&n=ACUERDOS-DEL-EXTINGUIDO-CABILDO-DE-BUENOS-AIRES|accessdate= }} ==Biography== Antonio was baptized on March 11, 1646 in the Main Church, being his godparents the Captain [[Diego Gutiérrez de Humanes]] and Leonor Carbajal.{{Citation |last= |first= |year= |title=Bautismos 1635-1636, 1640|publisher=Nuestra Señora de La Merced|publication-place= |page= |url=https://www.familysearch.org/ark:/61903/3:1:9396-XR55-G?i=24&cc=1974184|accessdate= }} His parents were [[:es:Cristóbal Cabral de Melo y Alpoin|Cristóbal Cabral de Melo]], an Azorean nobleman, born in [[Vila do Porto]], who served in the provincial militias as Captain of Cavalry and as Regidor of Buenos Aires,{{Citation |last= |first= |year= |title=Hombres del coloniaje:|publisher=Casa Oucinde, 1932|publication-place= |page= |url=https://books.google.com.ar/books?id=xxVlAAAAMAAJ&q=cristobal+cabral+de+melo+regidor&dq=cristobal+cabral+de+melo+regidor&hl=es&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiCoL6BrZDaAhXIDZAKHfdSBpMQ6AEILTAC|accessdate= }} and María de Carbajal, daughter of [[Gonzalo Carbajal]] and María de Salas, belonging to a distinguished family of Spanish colonizers.{{Citation |last= |first= |year= |title=Nupcias patricias: descendencia de los fundadores de la ciudad, siglos XVII-XVIII-XIX-XX|publisher=by Alberto A. Wildner-Fox|publication-place= |page= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CGoLAAAAYAAJ&q=cristobal+alpoin+antonio+cabral++maestre+de+campo&dq=cristobal+alpoin+antonio+cabral++maestre+de+campo&hl=es&sa=X&ei=2GdlVJnrJqrdsATJlIHYAg&ved=0CB0Q6AEwAA|accessdate= }} Antonio Cabral de Melo was married to Leonor Morales, daughter of [[Pedro Morales y Mercado]] and Mariana de Manzanares. The wedding was celebrated on July 13, 1671, in the [[Buenos Aires Cathedral|Cathedral Mayor]], and attended as godparents [[Juan Báez de Alpoim]] and Gerónima Cabral, relatives of the groom.{{Citation |last= |first= |year= |title=Matrimonios 1656-1762|publisher=Nuestra Señora de La Merced |publication-place= |page= |url=https://www.familysearch.org/ark:/61903/3:1:939D-VB9V-6G?i=53&cc=1974184|accessdate= }} His father-in-law, Don Pedro Morales y Mercado, had served as Mayor and Lieutenant of the Governor of Río de la Plata.{{Citation |last= |first= |year= |title=Revista del Archivo General de Buenos Aires, Volume 2|publisher=Archivo General de Buenos Aires|publication-place= |page= |url=https://books.google.com.ar/books?id=2GYMAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA183&dq=pedro+morales+y+mercado+alcalde+buenos+aires&hl=es-419&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiwh8uAuJDaAhVChZAKHRHkAV4Q6AEIJjAA#v=onepage&q=pedro%20morales%20y%20mercado%20alcalde%20buenos%20aires&f=false|accessdate= }} [[File:Enlazando ganado en las pampas - Fernando Brambilla - 1794.jpg|thumb|200px|left|Enlazando ganado en las pampas by [[Fernando Brambila]]]] After completing his studies at the [[Society of Jesus|Jesuit College]] of the city, Cabral de Melo was dedicated himself to the raising of [[livestock]], [[horses]] and [[pigs]]. He also devoted himself to [[agriculture]] and [[viticulture]].{{Citation |last= |first= |year= |title=Anuario del Instituto de Historia Argentina, Issues 5-6|publisher=Editorial de la Universidad Nacional de La Plata|publication-place= |page= |url=https://books.google.com.ar/books?id=VctxAAAAMAAJ&q=antonio+cabral+leonor+morales&dq=antonio+cabral+leonor+morales&hl=es-419&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjE6Nj07ZXaAhXDFpAKHbxLB6kQ6AEITjAJ|accessdate= }} He owned a large number of [[Hacienda|haciendas]], one of them was located in the center of [[Buenos Aires Province]].{{Citation |last= |first= |year= |title=El Fuerte 25 [i.e. veinticinco] de Mayo en Cruz de Guerra|publisher=Dirección de Impresiones Oficiales, 1949|publication-place= |page= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=h5poAAAAMAAJ&q=antonio+cabral+caravajal&dq=antonio+cabral+caravajal&hl=es&sa=X&ei=rV9lVPrOLtTIsATbj4DYAw&ved=0CCwQ6AEwAw|accessdate= }} He also participated in military expeditions against the Indians. He held the position of [[Maestre de Campo]], in charge of the provincial militias. Towards 1690 the town council authorized him to carry out the slaughter of the wild cattle that were in the jurisdiction of the province of Buenos Aires.{{Citation |last= |first= |year= |title=Acuerdos del extinguido Cabildo de Buenos Aires, Volumen 13|publisher=by Buenos Aires. Cabildo, José Juan Biedma, Augusto S. Mallié, Héctor C. Quesada, Eugenio Corbet France|publication-place= |page= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ApJoAAAAMAAJ&q=antonio+cabral+alpoin&dq=antonio+cabral+alpoin&hl=es&sa=X&ei=6m1lVIa-IoOhgwTL3IDoDA&ved=0CDMQ6AEwBA|accessdate= }} The "accioneros" of the cattle of the Río de la Plata, supplied meat and leather to the city during the 17th and 18th century, and were also in charge of the export of leather through of the [[:fr:Compagnie de Guinée|Compañía de Guinea de Francia]] and [[South Sea Company|Asiento de Inglaterra]] until 1740.{{Citation |last= |first= |year= |title=Evolución económica de la Banda Oriental, Volume 1|publisher=Lucía Sala de Touron, Julio C. Rodríguez, Nelson de la Torre|publication-place= |page= |url=https://books.google.com.ar/books?id=hBXRAAAAMAAJ&q=accioneros+cueros+asiento+buenos+aires&dq=accioneros+cueros+asiento+buenos+aires&hl=es-419&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjt56v0jpjaAhVR21MKHVZKA-8Q6AEIOTAE|accessdate= }} The right to the title of "accionero" was [[Heredity|inheritable]].{{Citation |last= |first= |year= |title=Nueva revista de Buenos Aires, Volume 4|publisher=C. Casavalle, 1882|publication-place= |page= |url=https://books.google.com.ar/books?id=KxMwAAAAYAAJ&q=accioneros+ganado+titulo+heredable&dq=accioneros+ganado+titulo+heredable&hl=es-419&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiAx9Gfk5jaAhWJ71MKHfXFC5cQ6AEIMDAC|accessdate= }} In 1668, Cabral de Melo requested to the Ayuntamiento for permission to hunt 3000 head of cattle in the area of [[Luján, Buenos Aires|Luján]], belonging to his mother Doña María de Carbajal.{{Citation |last= |first= |year= |title=Acuerdos del Extinguido Cabildo de Buenos Aires (1668-1672)|publisher=Archivo General de la Nación|publication-place= |page= |url=http://dgcultura.legislatura.gov.ar/cgi-bin/pgopac.cgi?VDOC=1.15543&n=ACUERDOS-DEL-EXTINGUIDO-CABILDO-DE-BUENOS-AIRES|accessdate= }} After the death of Antonio Cabral de Melo, the right to hunt cattle cimarron passed to his son-in-law Don Miguel Gerónimo de Esparza.{{Citation |last= |first= |year= |title=Acuerdos del extinguido Cabildo de Buenos Aires|publisher= Buenos Aires (Argentina). Cabildo|publication-place= |page= |url=https://books.google.com.ar/books?id=Z_dGujlXmKQC&q=antonio+cabral+esparza+accionero&dq=antonio+cabral+esparza+accionero&hl=es-419&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiPuc33lJjaAhWMiZAKHQq1BisQ6AEIJjAA|accessdate= }} After the extinction of cattle cimarron of Buenos Aires Province, the accioneros were dedicated entirely to the raising of cattle in their haciendas, trading their products with the [[Guipuzcoan Company of Caracas|Compañía Guipuzcoana]]{{Citation |last= |first= |year= |title=Resumen de la historia de Venezuela: |publisher=Rafael María Baralt, Ramón Díaz|publication-place= |page= |url=https://books.google.com.ar/books?id=0H9RAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA425&dq=cueros+Guipuzcoana+buenos+aires&hl=es-419&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiP-KLOm5raAhWLPpAKHX4RC5gQ6AEIKjAB#v=onepage&q=cueros%20Guipuzcoana%20buenos%20aires&f=false|accessdate= }} and [[:es:Compañía de Filipinas|Compañía de Filipinas]].{{Citation |last= |first= |year= |title=El Virreinato Rioplatense en las vistas fiscales de José Márquez de la Plata, Volume 2|publisher=Universidad del Museo Social Argentino|publication-place= |page= |url=https://books.google.com.ar/books?id=iPpIAQAAIAAJ&q=cueros+compa%C3%B1ia+de+filipinas&dq=cueros+compa%C3%B1ia+de+filipinas&hl=es-419&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiUm6u7nJraAhWFkZAKHTPBD18Q6AEIJjAA|accessdate= }} In 1707, Antonio Cabral de Melo, granted power to make his testament to [[Miguel de Riglos Bástida|Miguel de Riglos]], personal friend of the Cabral de Melo family. He was the nephew of [[Manuel Cabral de Alpoim]], a prominent rancher and military leader of Portuguese origin, who had an outstanding performance in the Río de la Plata, where he served as Mayor and Lieutenant of Governor of Corrientes.{{Citation |last= |first= |year= |title=Why Have You Come Here? : The Jesuits and the First Evangelization of Native ...|publisher=State University of New York|publication-place= |page= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Gl06Mf68a0sC&pg=PA101&dq=manuel+cabral+de+alpoim&hl=es&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwioq-OeuZrOAhUGOZAKHVpVDWQ4FBDoAQgsMAQ#v=onepage&q=manuel%20cabral%20de%20alpoim&f=false|accessdate= }} In 1627 he had obtained the title of Accionero Mayor del Ganado Vacuno of [[Corrientes]].{{Citation |last= |first= |year= |title=Historia de San Juan de Vera de las Siete Corrientes, 1588-1814|publisher=Raúl de Labougle|publication-place= |page= |url=https://books.google.com.ar/books?id=EsEZAAAAYAAJ&q=manuel+cabral+de+melo+accionero+mayor+del+ganado+vacuno&dq=manuel+cabral+de+melo+accionero+mayor+del+ganado+vacuno&hl=es-419&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiZptKelpjaAhWLhpAKHdAyCnYQ6AEILTAC|accessdate= }} ==References== ==External links== *[http://genealogiafamiliar.net/old/getperson.php?personID=I650441&tree=BVCZ Antonio Cabral de Melo in genealogia familiar] {{DEFAULTSORT:Cabral de Melo, Antonio}} [[Category:1646 births]] [[Category:1717 deaths]] [[Category:Spanish colonial governors and administrators]] [[Category:People from Buenos Aires]] [[Category:17th-century merchants]] [[Category:Landowners]] [[Category:17th-century Spanish businesspeople]] [[Category:18th-century Spanish businesspeople]] [[Category:18th-century Argentine people]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox scientist |name = Auroop Ratan Ganguly |image = Ganguly-a.jpg |residence = [[Massachusetts]],[[United States]] |birth_place = [[India]] |fields = Climate Extremes and Water Sustainability
Infrastructural Resilience and Homeland Security
Artificial Intelligence and Nonlinear Dynamics |alma_mater = [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]]
[[University of Toledo|University of Toledo, Ohio]]
[[Indian Institute of Technology Kharagpur]] |doctoral_advisor = [[Rafael L. Bras]] | workplaces = {{unbulleted list| [[Northeastern University]] | [[Oak Ridge National Laboratory]] | [[Oracle Corporation]]}} }} '''Auroop Ratan Ganguly''' is an American hydrologist and a [[civil engineer]] of [[India]]n origin best known for his work at the intersection of Climate Extremes and Water [[Sustainability]], [[Infrastructure|Infrastructural]] Resilience and Homeland Security; and [[Artificial Intelligence]] and [[Nonlinear Dynamics]]. == Academics == Ganguly received a Bachelor of Technology in [[Civil Engineering]] from [[Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur]] (1993), a Master of Science in Civil Engineering from [[University of Toledo]], Ohio (1997), and a PhD from the Civil and Environmental Engineering Department at the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]], Cambridge, Massachusetts (2002). == Professional work== Ganguly has been a faculty member at Northeastern University (NU), Boston, USA since 2013. He is currently a Professor of Civil and Environmental Engineering. He is also Professor by courtesy of multiple departments and colleges at NU, specifically, Computer and Information Science, Marine and Environmental Sciences, Political Science, and Public Policy and Urban Affairs, as well as a Visiting International Professor of Computer Science and Environmental Science at the [[Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur]]. Ganguly is the Director of the Sustainability and Data Sciences at NU.{{Cite web|url=https://web.northeastern.edu/sds/|title=Sustainability and Data Sciences (SDS) Lab @ NEU|website=web.northeastern.edu|access-date=2018-09-26}} Prior to his current position at Northeastern University in Boston, MA, he was at the [[United States Department of Energy|US Department of Energy's]] Oak Ridge National Laboratory for seven years in their Computational Sciences and Engineering Division, at [[Oracle Corporation]] for five years in their Time Series Database Kernel and Demand Forecasting E-business groups, and at a startup called [[List of acquisitions by Oracle|Demantra Inc.]], a demand forecasting company subsequently acquired by Oracle, for a year. In addition, he held joint and visiting faculty positions at the [[University of Tennessee]] in [[Knoxville]], Tennessee, and the [[University of South Florida]] in [[Tampa]], [[Florida]].   == Memberships == Ganguly is member of United Nations Environmental Program review panel {{Cite web|url=http://www.civ.neu.edu/news/cee-professor-ganguly-joins-united-nations-panel|title=CEE Professor Ganguly Joins United Nations Panel {{!}} Civil & Environmental Engineering {{!}} Northeastern University|website=www.civ.neu.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-09-26}} and the lead author of the Artificial Intelligence (AI) section of the 2018 Sustained National Climate Assessment of the United States.{{Cite web|url=http://www.civ.neu.edu/news/ganguly-leads-artificial-intelligence-section-us-climate-assessment|title=Ganguly leads Artificial Intelligence section for US Climate Assessment {{!}} Civil & Environmental Engineering {{!}} Northeastern University|website=www.civ.neu.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-09-26}} He is currently on the editorial board of Nature's [[Scientific Reports]], and [[PLOS One]]. He is also an Associate Editor of [[American Society of Civil Engineers|ASCE]] Journal of Computing in Civil Engineering. He has previously served as an Associate Editor of the American Geophysical Union (AGU) journal [[Water Resources Research]], on the AI committee of the [[American Meteorological Society]] (AMS), and as a co-chair of the Societal Dimensions Working Group at the [[National Center for Atmospheric Research]] (NCAR).{{Cite web|url=http://www.cesm.ucar.edu/working_groups/Societal/|title=SDWG {{!}} Societal Dimensions Working Group|website=www.cesm.ucar.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-09-26}} Ganguly is the co-founder and chief scientific adviser at the Cambridge, Massachusetts-based NSF-funded startup{{Cite web|url=https://nsf.gov/awardsearch/showAward?AWD_ID=1758286&HistoricalAwards=false|title=NSF Award Search: Award#1758286 - SBIR Phase II: Climate Analytics Platform for Catastrophe Modeling and Risk Management|website=nsf.gov|access-date=2018-09-26}} risQ.{{Cite web|url=http://risq.io/|title=risQ - Home|website=risq.io|access-date=2018-09-26}} ==Research Areas== Ganguly's research across the fields on water and climate science, infrastructures resilience and security, as well as machine learning and nonlinear dynamics. He develops fundamental insights about weather extremes and water sustainability, innovative ways to reduce fragility of infrastructures, and new adaptations of data science. Thus, research teams led by him have been among the first to suggest the possibility of persisting cold snaps under global warming,{{Cite journal|last=Kodra|first=Evan|last2=Steinhaeuser|first2=Karsten|last3=Ganguly|first3=Auroop R.|date=2011-04-27|title=Persisting cold extremes under 21st-century warming scenarios|journal=Geophysical Research Letters|language=en|volume=38|issue=8|pages=n/a|doi=10.1029/2011gl047103|issn=0094-8276}} point to growing spatial variability of extreme rainfall during the Indian monsoon,{{Cite journal|last=Ghosh|first=Subimal|last2=Das|first2=Debasish|last3=Kao|first3=Shih-Chieh|last4=Ganguly|first4=Auroop R.|date=2011-12-18|title=Lack of uniform trends but increasing spatial variability in observed Indian rainfall extremes|url=https://www.nature.com/articles/nclimate1327|journal=Nature Climate Change|language=En|volume=2|issue=2|pages=86–91|doi=10.1038/nclimate1327|issn=1758-678X}} translate scientific understanding of precipitation extremes under climate change to intensity-duration-frequency curves relevant for the design of hydraulic infrastructures,{{Cite journal|last=Kao|first=Shih-Chieh|last2=Ganguly|first2=Auroop R.|date=2011-08-26|title=Intensity, duration, and frequency of precipitation extremes under 21st-century warming scenarios|journal=Journal of Geophysical Research|language=en|volume=116|issue=D16|doi=10.1029/2010jd015529|issn=0148-0227}} develop efficient recovery strategies for damaged critical lifeline networks,{{Cite journal|last=Bhatia|first=Udit|last2=Kumar|first2=Devashish|last3=Kodra|first3=Evan|last4=Ganguly|first4=Auroop R.|date=2015-11-04|title=Network Science Based Quantification of Resilience Demonstrated on the Indian Railways Network|journal=PLOS ONE|language=en|volume=10|issue=11|pages=e0141890|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0141890|issn=1932-6203|pmc=4633230|pmid=26536227}}{{Cite news|url=https://phys.org/news/2015-11-tool-recovery-disasters.html|title=Researchers develop a new tool to guide recovery from disasters|access-date=2018-09-26}}{{cite web|url=https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/8306449|title=Resilience of the US National Airspace System Airport Network - IEEE Journals & Magazine|website=ieeexplore.ieee.org}} rigorously compare methods to examine nonlinear relations among short and noisy data,{{Cite journal|last=Khan|first=Shiraj|last2=Bandyopadhyay|first2=Sharba|last3=Ganguly|first3=Auroop R.|last4=Saigal|first4=Sunil|last5=Erickson|first5=David J.|last6=Protopopescu|first6=Vladimir|last7=Ostrouchov|first7=George|date=2007-08-14|title=Relative performance of mutual information estimation methods for quantifying the dependence among short and noisy data|journal=Physical Review E|volume=76|issue=2|pages=026209|doi=10.1103/PhysRevE.76.026209|pmid=17930123|hdl=2047/d20002073}} develop hybrid physics and data science methods for weather and climate extremes,{{Cite journal|last=Ganguly|first=A. R.|last2=Kodra|first2=E. A.|last3=Agrawal|first3=A.|last4=Banerjee|first4=A.|last5=Boriah|first5=S.|last6=Chatterjee|first6=Sn|last7=Chatterjee|first7=So|last8=Choudhary|first8=A.|last9=Das|first9=D.|date=2014-07-28|title=Toward enhanced understanding and projections of climate extremes using physics-guided data mining techniques|url=https://www.nonlin-processes-geophys.net/21/777/2014/npg-21-777-2014.html|journal=Nonlinear Processes in Geophysics|language=English|volume=21|issue=4|pages=777–795|doi=10.5194/npg-21-777-2014|issn=1023-5809}} and new machine learning{{Cite book|last=Vandal|first=Thomas|last2=Kodra|first2=Evan|last3=Ganguly|first3=Sangram|last4=Michaelis|first4=Andrew|last5=Nemani|first5=Ramakrishna|last6=Ganguly|first6=Auroop R.|date=2017-08-13|title=DeepSD: Generating High Resolution Climate Change Projections through Single Image Super-Resolution|url=http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=3097983.3098004|publisher=ACM|pages=1663–1672|doi=10.1145/3097983.3098004|isbn=9781450348874}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.kdd.org/awards/view/2017-sigkdd-best-paper-award-winners|title=SIGKDD Awards : 2017 SIGKDD Best Paper Award Winners|last=News|first=SIGKDD|website=www.kdd.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-09-26}}{{Cite web|url=https://archive.siam.org/meetings/sdm12/|title=SIAM: SIAM International Conference on Data Mining (SDM12)|website=archive.siam.org|access-date=2018-09-26}} and network science methods for representing and projecting complex space-time and graphical data.{{Cite journal|last=Steinhaeuser|first=Karsten|last2=Ganguly|first2=Auroop R.|last3=Chawla|first3=Nitesh V.|date=2011-06-30|title=Multivariate and multiscale dependence in the global climate system revealed through complex networks|journal=Climate Dynamics|language=en|volume=39|issue=3–4|pages=889–895|doi=10.1007/s00382-011-1135-9|issn=0930-7575}} His research informs governments, companies, communities, and people in the broad area of climate adaptation and resilient engineering for urban sustainability and rural development with an emphasis on becoming resilient to changes and extreme events.https://www.boston.gov/sites/default/files/document-file-12-2016/brag_report_-_final.pdf{{Cite web|url=http://www.civ.neu.edu/news/climate-ready-boston-report|title=Climate Ready Boston Report {{!}} Civil & Environmental Engineering {{!}} Northeastern University|website=www.civ.neu.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-09-26}}{{Cite news|url=https://thrivingearthexchange.org/project/brookline-ma/|title=Building Community Resilience to Extreme Heat - Thriving Earth Exchange|work=Thriving Earth Exchange|access-date=2018-09-26|language=en-US}} Ganguly's research has been cited in United Nations and US assessment reports, highlighted in commentaries in scientific venues such as Nature,{{cite journal|url=https://www.nature.com/articles/472139d|title=Cold spells in a warm world|date=1 April 2011|publisher=|journal=Nature|volume=472|issue=7342|pages=139–139|doi=10.1038/472139d}} PNAS, NASA Tech Briefs, R&D Magazine,{{Cite news|url=https://www.rdmag.com/news/2014/07/climate-change-research-goes-extremes|title=Climate change research goes to the extremes|date=2014-07-30|work=Research & Development|access-date=2018-09-26|language=en}} US Department of Energy (DOE), and National Science Foundation (NSF) news,{{Cite web|url=http://www.civ.neu.edu/news/nsf-highlights-gangulys-work|title=NSF Highlights Ganguly's Work {{!}} Civil & Environmental Engineering {{!}} Northeastern University|website=www.civ.neu.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-09-26}} while he and his work have been quoted by the news media in the US{{Cite news|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/news/nation/2012/03/28/mumbai-miami-list-for-big-weather-disasters-panel-says/WgCbfgnJRDudGKlJBaeiWJ/story.html|title=Mumbai, Miami on list for big weather disasters, panel says - The Boston Globe|work=BostonGlobe.com|access-date=2018-09-26}}{{Cite news|url=http://news.mit.edu/2018/alumni-call-mit-champion-artificial-intelligence-public-good-0209|title=Alumni call on MIT to champion artificial intelligence education|work=MIT News|access-date=2018-09-26}} and across the globe.{{Cite web|url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/12/hurricane-season-171204094454534.html|title=The hurricane season comes to an end|website=www.aljazeera.com|access-date=2018-09-26}}{{cite web|url=https://phys.org/news/2015-11-tool-recovery-disasters.html|title=Researchers develop a new tool to guide recovery from disasters|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=https://gulfnews.com/news/americas/usa/nations-should-prepare-for-weather-disasters-1.1001677|title=Nations should prepare for weather disasters|first=|last=AP|date=30 March 2012|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.ndtv.com/world-news/mumbai-miami-on-list-for-big-weather-disasters-473869|title=Mumbai, Miami on list for big weather disasters|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.ndtv.com/indians-abroad/indian-origin-researchers-in-us-discover-tool-to-help-recover-from-disasters-1244072|title=Indian-Origin Researchers in US Discover Tool to Help Recover From Disasters|publisher=}} ==Books== * ''Critical Infrastructures Resilience'', with Udit Bhatia and Stephen Flynn, [[Routledge]], 2018 * ''Knowledge Discovery from Sensor Data'', Auroop R. {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2017}} {{Use British English|date=April 2017}} {{Infobox military person |honorific_prefix = |name =Bartholomew Samuel Rowley |honorific_suffix = |native_name = |native_name_lang = |image = |image_size = |alt = |caption = |birth_date ={{birth date|1764|06|10|df=y}} |death_date ={{Death date and age|1811|10|07|1764|06|10|df=y}} |birth_place = |death_place =Jamaica |placeofburial = |placeofburial_label = |placeofburial_coordinates = |nickname = |birth_name = |allegiance ={{flag|United Kingdom|23px}} |branch ={{navy|United Kingdom|23px}} |serviceyears =1777–1811 |rank =[[Admiral (Royal Navy)|Admiral]] |servicenumber = |unit = |commands ={{HMS|Resource|1778|6}}
{{HMS|Diamond|1774|6}}
{{HMS|Penelope|1783|6}}
{{HMS|Cumberland|1774|6}}
{{HMS|Ramillies|1785|6}}
[[Downs Station|The Downs]]
[[Jamaica Station]] |battles ={{Plainlist | * [[American Revolutionary War]] * [[French Revolutionary Wars]] * • [[Battle of Hyères Islands]] * [[Napoleonic Wars]] }} |battles_label = |awards = |spouse = |relations =[[William Rowley (Royal Navy officer)|Sir William Rowley]] (grandfather)
[[Sir Joshua Rowley, 1st Baronet|Sir Joshua Rowley]] (father) |laterwork = |signature = |website = }} Admiral Sir '''Bartholomew Samuel Rowley''' (10 June 1764 – 7 October 1811{{cite book |editor-last=Mosley |editor-first=Charles |editor-link=Charles Mosley (genealogist) |title=Burke's Peerage, Baronetage & Knightage |url=http://thepeerage.com/p31606.htm |accessdate=3 December 2012 |edition=107th |volume=3 |year=2003 |publisher=Burke's Peerage (Genealogical Books) Ltd |location=Wilmington, Delaware |isbn= |page=3421 }}) was a British naval officer who served during the [[American Revolutionary War|American]], [[French Revolutionary Wars|French Revolutionary]] and [[Napoleonic Wars]]. [[File:Bartholomew Samuel Rowley memorial.jpg|thumb|Memorial to Bartholomew Rowley in St Mary's church, Stoke-by-Nayland, Suffolk]] ==Biography== He was second son of [[Vice admiral (Royal Navy)|Vice-Admiral]] [[Sir Joshua Rowley, 1st Baronet|Sir Joshua Rowley]], and was a member of a notable naval dynasty; his grandfather was [[Admiral of the Fleet (Royal Navy)|Admiral of the Fleet]] [[William Rowley (Royal Navy officer)|Sir William Rowley]], while his younger brother was Admiral Sir Charles Rowley, and his cousins included Admiral [[Sir Josias Rowley, 1st Baronet|Sir Josias Rowley]], Rear-Admiral Samuel Campbell Rowley, Vice-Admiral Sir Joshua Ricketts Rowley, and Admiral of the Fleet [[George Martin (Royal Navy officer)|Sir George Martin]]. His sister Philadelphia Rowley was married to Admiral [[Sir Charles Cotton, 5th Baronet|Sir Charles Cotton]].{{cite web |url=http://www.turtlebunbury.com/family/bunburyfamily_related/bunbury_family_related_campbell.html |title=Letitia Campbell & The Rowley Connection |last1=Bunbury |first1=Turtle |year=2005 |work=turtlebunbury.com |accessdate=3 December 2012}} Rowley attended [[Harrow School]] from 1775,{{cite web |url=http://www.harrowassociation.com/netcommunity/document.doc?id=190 |title=The Timeline History of Harrow School |last1=Vargas |first1=Dale |year=2010 |work=harrowassociation.com |accessdate=3 December 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120316052830/http://www.harrowassociation.com/NetCommunity/Document.Doc?id=190 |archivedate=16 March 2012 |df=dmy-all }} and then entered in the Navy. By 1780 was serving as a [[Lieutenant (navy)|lieutenant]] aboard his father's [[flagship]], the [[Seventy-four (ship)|74-gun]] {{HMS|Conqueror|1773|2}}. On 31 January 1781 he was [[Post-captain|made post]]Clowes (1899), p.195 (before his 17th birthday!) in order to command the 28-gun [[sixth-rate]] frigate {{HMS|Resource|1778|2}}.{{cite book |last1=Foster |first1=Kathleen A. |title=The Sketchbooks and Diary of Joshua Rowley Watson, 1772-1818 |url= https://www.nytimes.com/books/first/f/foster-watson.html |accessdate=3 December 2012 |year=1997 |publisher=[[University of Pennsylvania Press]] |location=Philadelphia |isbn=0-8122-3384-0 }} On 20 April 1781 ''Resource'' captured the 20-gun French frigate ''Licorne'' in an action lasting 1½ hours.Clowes (1899), p.63 She proved to be the former {{HMS|Unicorn|1776|6}}, which had been captured on 4 September 1780 by a French frigate and two ships of the line off [[Tortuga (Haiti)|Tortuga]].Clowes (1899), p.57 In October 1782 Rowley took command of the [[fifth-rate]] 32-gun frigate {{HMS|Diamond|1774|2}}, where he served until August 1783. However, with the end of the American Revolutionary War in September 1783, Rowley found himself, like many other naval officers, unemployed on [[half-pay]] for nearly a decade. By the time of the outbreak of the French Revolutionary War in February 1793 Rowley was back at sea in command of the 32-gun frigate {{HMS|Penelope|1783|2}}, serving in the [[Jamaica Squadron]], under the command of Commodore John Ford.Clowes (1899), p.197 On 16 April 1793 ''Penelope'' captured the French [[aviso]] ''Le Goéland'', commanded by ''[[Ship-of-the-line lieutenant|lieutenant de vaisseau]]'' Leissègues de Pennenyum, en route from [[Cap-Haïtien|Cap-Français]] to [[Jérémie]].{{cite web | url=http://www.servicehistorique.sga.defense.gouv.fr/contenu/functions/dc/attached/FRSHD_PUB_00000226_dc/FRSHD_PUB_00000226_dc_att-FRSHD_PUB_00000226_01.pdf | title=Fonds Marine Campagnes (1790-1804) | date=December 2010 | publisher=[[Service Historique de la Défense]] | location=[[Vincennes]] | page=54 | language=French |trans-title=Naval Campaigns Records (1790-1804) | format=PDF | accessdate=3 December 2012 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140306204735/http://www.servicehistorique.sga.defense.gouv.fr/contenu/functions/dc/attached/FRSHD_PUB_00000226_dc/FRSHD_PUB_00000226_dc_att-FRSHD_PUB_00000226_01.pdf | archivedate=6 March 2014 | df=dmy-all }} In late 1793 Ford took advantage of the [[Haitian Revolution]] to occupy several ports in the French colony of [[Saint-Domingue]] (now [[Haiti]]). On 20 November 1793 ''Penelope'' sailed from [[Môle-Saint-Nicolas]], having received news that the French 36-gun frigate ''L'Inconstante'' was sailing from [[Port-au-Prince]], escorting a large merchant ship. The next day ''Penelope'' met the 32-gun frigate {{HMS|Iphigenia|1780|2}} and the two ships proceeded towards Port-au-Prince. However they learned that ''L'Inconstante'' had sailed to [[Petit-Trou-de-Nippes|Petit Trou]] with two mail ships, but was soon expected to return to port. They intended to [[cutting out operation|cut her out]] of the harbour of Port-au-Prince, but on the night of 25 November met her at sea, and after a brisk exchange of broadsides, ''L'Inconstante'' surrendered. The ''Penelope'' had only one man killed and seven wounded, while the ''L'Inconstante'' had nine killed, including the Captain and the First Lieutenant, and 17 wounded.{{London Gazette |issue=13622 |date=8 February 1794 |page=129 }} On 2 January 1794 Ford sent ''Penelope'' into Port-au-Prince under a [[flag of truce]] where Rowley demanded the surrender of the island from the French Civil Commissioner [[Léger-Félicité Sonthonax]]. He refused, and the British promptly blockaded the island.{{London Gazette |issue=13631 |date=11 March 1794 |page=227 }} After the capture of Port-au-Prince on 4 June 1794, Rowley and Lieutenant-Colonel [[John Whitelocke]] were sent back to England with dispatches aboard the [[Sloop-of-war|sloop]] {{HMS|Fly|1776|2}}.{{cite web |url=http://www.ageofnelson.org/MichaelPhillips/info.php?ref=0930 |title=FLY |last=Phillips |first=Michael |author= |year=2012 |work= Ships of the Old Navy |accessdate=3 December 2012 }} In August 1794 Rowley was appointed captain of the 74-gun {{HMS|Cumberland|1774|2}},{{Cite book |last1=Winfield |first1=Rif |title=[[British Warships in the Age of Sail]] 1714-1792 |year=2007 |publisher=Seaforth Publishing |location= |isbn=978-1-84415-700-6 }} taking part in the [[Battle of Hyères Islands]] on 13 July 1795, off the southern coast of France, when a British fleet under Admiral [[William Hotham, 1st Baron Hotham|William Hotham]] engaged a French fleet. ''Cumberland'' was in the [[vanguard (military formation)|van]] of the British fleet, accepting the surrender of the French 74 {{Ship|French ship|Alcide|1782|2}}, before Hotham ordered the fleet to disengage.Clowes, pp. 274-277 From July 1797 until October 1798 Rowley commanded the 74-gun {{HMS|Ramillies|1785|2}}, capturing the French [[brig]] ''L'Arrogant''.{{London Gazette |issue=15138 |date=25 May 1799 |page=509 }} Rowley was promoted to Rear-Admiral on 14 February 1799,{{London Gazette |issue=15107 |date=12 February 1799 |page=148 }} and to Vice-Admiral on 9 November 1805.{{London Gazette |issue=15859 |date=5 November 1805 |page=1374 }} He was appointed Commander-in-Chief at [[Downs Station|The Downs]] in 1807{{cite book|last1=Urban|first1=Sylvanus|title=Gentleman's Magazine, and Historical Chronicle|date=1811|publisher=E. Cave, London|page=586|url=https://books.google.lk/books?id=TtNKAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA586&dq=Vice-Admiral+Bartholomew+Rowley+Downs+Station&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwithLLEvsvSAhXHurwKHXT1CccQ6AEISTAJ#v=onepage&q=Vice-Admiral%20Bartholomew%20Rowley%20Downs%20Station&f=false|language=en}} and Commander-in-Chief at the [[Jamaica Station]] in 1808,Cundall, p. xx and sailed from England in July 1808 aboard {{HMS|Polyphemus|1782|2}}, commanded by Captain [[William Pryce Cumby]]. As C-in-C Rowley resided ashore, flying his flag in {{HMS|Shark|1779|2}}.{{cite web |url=http://www.ageofnelson.org/MichaelPhillips/info.php?ref=1756 |title=POLYPHEMUS (64) |last=Phillips |first=Michael |author= |year=2012 |work= Ships of the Old Navy |accessdate=3 December 2012 }} He was promoted to [[Admiral of the Blue]] on 31 July 1810,{{London Gazette |issue=16391 |date=28 July 1810 |page=1118 }} and died at Jamaica on 7 October 1811. ==References== ;Notes {{reflist}} ;Bibliography * {{cite book |last1=Clowes |first1=William Laird |authorlink1=William Laird Clowes |title=The Royal Navy: A History From the Earliest Times to the Present |url=https://archive.org/details/royalnavy04clow |accessdate=3 December 2012 |volume=Vol. IV |year=1899 |publisher=Sampson Low, Marston & Company |location=London }} *{{cite book|url=https://archive.org/stream/cu31924020417527#page/n27/mode/2up|title=Historic Jamaica|first=Frank|last=Cundall|publisher=West India Committee|year=1915}} {{s-start}} {{s-mil}} {{s-bef|before=[[John Holloway (Royal Navy officer)|John Holloway]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Downs Station|Commander-in-Chief, The Downs]]|years=1807–1808}} {{s-aft|after=[[George Campbell (Royal Navy officer)|George Campbell]]}} |- {{s-bef | before=[[James Richard Dacres (1749–1810)|James Richard Dacres]]}} {{s-ttl | title=[[Jamaica Station|Commander-in-Chief, Jamaica Station]]| years=1809–1811}} {{s-aft | after=[[Charles Stirling]]}} {{s-end}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Rowley, Bartholomew Samuel}} [[Category:1764 births]] [[Category:1811 deaths]] [[Category:People educated at Harrow School]] [[Category:People of the Haitian Revolution]] [[Category:Royal Navy personnel of the American Revolutionary War]] [[Category:Royal Navy personnel of the French Revolutionary Wars]] [[Category:British naval commanders of the Napoleonic Wars]] [[Category:Royal Navy admirals]]

revision.comment: copyedits
revision.text:
When studying [[literature]], '''biography and its relationship to literature''' is often a subject of [[literary criticism]], and is treated in several different forms. Two scholarly approaches use [[biography]] or biographical approaches to the past as a tool for interpreting literature: '''literary biography''' and [[biographical criticism]]. Additionally, two genres of fiction rely heavily on the incorporation of biographical elements into their content, [[biographical novel|biographical fiction]] and [[autofiction|autobiographical fiction]].
==Literary biography== A literary biography is the biographical exploration of the lives of writers and artists. Biographies about artists and writers are sometimes some of the most complicated forms of biography.<ref name = backschneider1113/> Not only does the author of the biography have to write about the subject of the biography but also must incorporate discussion of the individual's literary works into the biography itself.<ref name = backschneider1113/><ref name = karl>Karl, Frederick R. "Joseph Conrad" in Meyers (ed.) ''The Craft'', pp 69–88</ref> Literary biographers must balance the weight of commentary on the individual works against the biographical content to create a coherent narrative.<ref name = backschneider1113/> This balance is affected by the degree of biographical elements in an author's literary works. The close relationship between writers and their work relies on ideas that connect human psychology and literature and can be examined through [[psychoanalytic theory]].<ref name = karl/>
Literary biography tends to have a plethora of autobiographical sources. Elizabeth Longford, a biographer of [[Wilfrid Blunt]], noted, "Writers are articulate and tend to leave eloquent source material which the biographer will be eager to use."<ref name= longford>Longford, Elizabeth "Wilfrid Scawen Blunt" of Meyers (ed.) ''The Craft'', pp 55-68</ref> However, some authors and artists go out of their way to discourage the writing of their biographies, as was the case with Kafka, Eliot, Orwell and Auden. Auden said, "Biographies of writers whether written by others or themselves are always superfluous and usually in bad taste.... His private life is, or should be, of no concern to anybody except himself, his family and his friends."<ref name = meyers>Meyers, Jeffrey "Introduction" in Meyers (ed.) ''The Craft'', pp 1–8</ref>
Well-received literary biographies include [[Richard Ellmann]]'s ''James Joyce'' and [[George Painter]]'s ''Marcel Proust''.<ref name = backschneider1113>Backschneider 11-13</ref><ref name = meyers/>
==Biographical criticism== {{main|Biographical criticism}} Biographical criticism is the deliberate use of biographical information to shed light on the difference created by experience between an author and his audience, and so provide insight into how to understand that particular work.<ref>{{cite journal| last = Benson| first = Jackson J| year = 1989| jstor = 25111810| title = Steinbeck: A Defense of Biographical Criticism| journal = College Literature| issue = 16| volume = 29| pages = 107–116}}</ref>
==Biographical fiction== {{see also|Biographical novel|Biographical film}} Biographical fiction is a type of [[historical fiction]] that takes a historical individual and recreates elements of his or her life, while telling a fictional narrative, usually in the genres of film or the novel. The relationship between the biographical and the fictional may vary within different pieces of biographical fiction. It frequently includes selective information and self-censoring of the past. The characters are often real people or based on real people, but the need for "truthful" representation is less strict than in [[biography]].
The various philosophies behind biographical fiction lead to different types of content. Some asserts itself as a factual narrative about the historical individual, like [[Gore Vidal]]'s ''[[Lincoln (novel)|Lincoln]]''. Other biographical fiction creates two parallel strands of narrative, one in the contemporary world and one focusing on the biographical history, such as [[Malcolm Bradbury]]'s ''[[To the Hermitage]]'' and [[Michael Cunningham]]'s ''[[The Hours (novel)|The Hours]]''. No matter what style of biographical fiction is used, the novelist usually starts the writing process with historical research.<ref name="mullan" />
Biographical fiction has its roots in late 19th and early 20th-century novels based loosely on the lives of famous people, but without direct reference to them, such as [[George Meredith]]'s ''[[Diana of the Crossways]]'' (1885) and [[Somerset Maugham]]'s ''[[The Moon and Sixpence]]'' (1919). During the early part of the 20th century this became a distinct genre, with novels that were explicitly about individuals' lives.<ref name = mullan>{{cite news| title = Heavy on the source John Mullan analyses The Master by Colm Tóibín. Week three: biographical fiction| first = John| last = Mullan| newspaper =The Guardian| date = 30 April 2005| url = https://www.theguardian.com/books/2005/apr/30/fiction.colmtoibin}}</ref>
==Autobiographical fiction== {{main|Autofiction}} {{see also|Autobiographical novel|Autobiographical comics}} Autobiographical fiction, or autofiction, is fiction that incorporates the author's own experience into the narrative. It allows authors to both rely and reflect on their own experience. However, the reading of the autobiographical fiction need not always be associated with the author. Such books may be treated as distinct fictional works.<ref name = bragg>{{cite news| url = http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/books/article5668638.ece| newspaper = The Sunday Times| date = 8 February 2009| title = Melvyn Bragg on autobiographical fiction| accessdate = 9 June 2011}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
===Works cited=== *{{Cite book|publisher = Oxford University Press |publication-place = Oxford |title = Reflections on biography |url = http://openlibrary.org/books/OL42046M/Reflections_on_biography |first = Paula R.| last = Backscheider |publication-date = 1999 |isbn = 0-19-818641-X }} *{{Cite book| title = The Craft of Literary Biography| editor = Jeffrey Meyers| publisher = MacMillan| year = 1985| publication-place = London| isbn = 0-333-37348-0}}
==Further reading== *{{Cite book| title = The Literary Biography| editor = Dale Salwak| year =1996| publisher = Macmillan| publication-place = Basingstoke, Hampshire| isbn = 978-0333626399}}
