revision.text:
'''Susan Elderkin''' (born 1968<ref name=bc>[http://literature.britishcouncil.org/susan-elderkin Susan Elderkin | British Council Literature]</ref> in [[Crawley]]<ref name=nwp>[http://www.newwritingpartnership.org.uk/nwp/site/writer-243.html New Writing Partnership : New Writing Season]</ref>) is an English author of two critically acclaimed novels, her first, ''[[Sunset Over Chocolate Mountains]]'' won a [[Betty Trask Prize]] and was shortlisted for the [[Orange Prize for Fiction]],<ref>[http://www.suehubbard.com/reviews/susan_elderkin.shtml Susan Elderkin The Voices]</ref> her second, ''The Voices'' was shortlisted for the [[Ondaatje Prize]] and longlisted for the [[International IMPAC Dublin Literary Award]]. She was one of [[Granta Magazine]]'s 20 Best Young British Novelists in 2003 and won the 2007 [[Society of Authors]] Travel Award.<ref name=bc/><ref>[http://www.societyofauthors.org/betty-trask-past-winners Betty Trask Past Winners]</ref><ref name=W9>http://www.afghanearthworks.com/ranpura/W9_Writers/About_Susan.html About Susan</ref>
==Life== Elderkin grew up in [[Leatherhead, Surrey]] and studied English at [[Downing College, Cambridge]]<ref>[http://www.granta.com/Contributors/Susan-Elderkin Granta Contributors: Susan Elderkin]</ref> then an MA on the [[UEA Creative Writing Course]] taught by [[Malcolm Bradbury]] and [[Rose Tremain]]. She went on to become a travel writer, journalist and reviewer, mainly for the ''[[Financial Times]]''<ref name=aitken>[http://www.aitkenalexander.co.uk/index.php?option=com_k2&view=itemlist&task=user&id=497%3Asusanelderkin&Itemid=151 Aitken Alexander Associates]</ref> and to teach creative writing herself at [[Goldsmith's College]], [[Birkbeck, University of London]], [[City University London]], the [[Arvon Foundation]] and [[Manchester University]].<ref name=bc/><ref name=nwp/><ref name=W9/> She has also worked as an ice-cream seller and taught English at a [[Slovakia]]n shoe factory.<ref>[http://www.harpercollins.com.au/authors/50017631/Susan_Elderkin/index.aspx Susan Elderkin from HarperCollins Publishers Australia]</ref> She lives between [[Somerset]] and America with her partner and young son<ref name=aitken/> and is working on adapting her first novel for film.<ref name=nwp/> She is a [[bibliotherapy|bibliotherapist]] at [[The School of Life]]<ref>http://www.theschooloflife.com/shop/individual-bibliotherapy/ Bibliotherapy</ref> and is currently writing a book called ''The Novel Cure'' with fellow therapist Ella Berthoud which will prescribe novels to read to aid in various ailments.<ref name=aitken/>
==Bibliography==
===Novels=== *''[[Sunset Over Chocolate Mountains]]'' (2000) *''The Voices'' (2003) - The story, set in the western Australian outback, is about a boy who is found ten years after disappearing into the Outback following ghostly voices.<ref>[[The Guardian]] [https://www.theguardian.com/books/2003/jun/14/featuresreviews.guardianreview21 Review]</ref>
===Short Stories=== *"This One (or How The [[Blackthorn]] Got Its Flowers)" (2011) - appears in ''Why Willows Weep: Contemporary Tales from the Woods'', published by IndieBooks in association with [[The Woodland Trust]]<ref>[http://www.woodlandtrust.org.uk/en/support-us/why-willows-weep/Pages/synopsis.aspx Why Willows Weep by the Woodland Trust - Fantastic Short Stories by famous authors]</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{official website|http://www.susanelderkin.com/}} *[https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/feature.html?ie=UTF8&docId=127310 An interview with Susan Elderkin] *[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/features/3638082/Culture-clinic-Susan-Elderkin.html Culture clinic: Susan Elderkin] from ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' *[http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/79b7f75a-be2c-11db-bd86-0000779e2340.html#axzz27tFsicGb ''The Reader's Digest'' by Susan Elderkin] from [[FT.com]]
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Elderkin, Susan}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1968 births]] [[Category:English women novelists]] [[Category:21st-century British novelists]] [[Category:People from Crawley]] [[Category:People from Leatherhead]] [[Category:Alumni of Downing College, Cambridge]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of East Anglia]] [[Category:Academics of Goldsmiths, University of London]] [[Category:Academics of Birkbeck, University of London]] [[Category:Academics of the University of Manchester]] [[Category:Financial Times people]] [[Category:Bibliotherapy]] [[Category:21st-century British women writers]] [[Category:The School of Life people]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox officeholder | honorific-prefix = The Right Honourable | name = The Marquess of Dufferin and Ava | honorific-suffix = [[Deputy Lieutenant|DL]] [[Justice of the Peace|JP]] | image = | caption = | birth_name = Terence John Temple Hamilton-Temple-Blackwood | birth_date = {{birth-date|16 March 1866|}} | birth_place = | death_date = {{death date and age|df=yes|1918|02|07|1866|03|16}} | death_place = [[London]], [[England]] | residence = [[Clandeboye Estate]], [[County Down]] | nationality = British | party = | alma_mater = | parents = [[Frederick Hamilton-Temple-Blackwood, 1st Marquess of Dufferin and Ava|1st Marquess of Dufferin and Ava]]
[[Hariot Hamilton-Temple-Blackwood, Marchioness of Dufferin and Ava|Marchioness of Dufferin and Ava]] | spouse = {{marriage|Florence "Flora" Davis
|1893|1918|reason=his death}} | children = 3 | signature = }} '''Terence John Temple Hamilton-Temple-Blackwood, 2nd Marquess of Dufferin and Ava''' [[Deputy Lieutenant|DL]] [[Justice of the Peace|JP]] (16 March 1866 – 7 February 1918), styled '''Lord Terence Blackwood''' between 1888 and 1900 and '''Earl of Ava''' between 1900 and 1902, was a [[United Kingdom|British]] [[diplomat]].{{cite book|last1=Hammond, editor|first1=Peter W.|title=The Complete Peerage or a History of the House of Lords and All its Members From the Earliest Times, Volume XIV|date=1998|publisher=Addenda & Corrigenda {{!}} Stroud {{!}} Sutton Publishing|location=Gloucestershire, U.K.|page=281|url=http://thepeerage.com/p4999.htm|accessdate=8 November 2017}} ==Early life== Lord Dufferin was the second son of [[Frederick Hamilton-Temple-Blackwood, 1st Marquess of Dufferin and Ava]] and [[Hariot Hamilton-Temple-Blackwood, Marchioness of Dufferin and Ava]].{{cite book|last1=Black|first1=Charles Edward Drummond|title=The Marquess of Dufferin and Ava: Diplomatist, Viceroy, Statesman|date=1903|publisher=Hutchinson|page=392|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9YdnAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA392&lpg=PA392|accessdate=8 November 2017|language=en}}{{cite news|title=A Biography of Dufferin.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1903/04/11/archives/a-biography-of-dufferin.html|accessdate=8 November 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=11 April 1903}} As a younger son, he was not expected to inherit the title, but on the death of his brother Archibald, Earl of Ava at the [[Siege of Ladysmith]] in the [[Second Boer War]] on 11 January 1900,{{cite book|title=The Current Encyclopedia: A Monthly Record of Human Progress|date=1902|publisher=Hearst's International|page=1124|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6I_NAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA1124&lpg=PA1124|accessdate=8 November 2017|language=en}} he became the heir and assumed the [[courtesy title]] Earl of Ava himself before succeeding his father in 1902.{{cite web|title=Terence John Temple Hamilton-Temple-Blackwood, 2nd Marquess of Dufferin and Ava|url=https://thepeerage.com/p4999.htm|website=thepeerage.com|publisher=[[The Peerage]]|accessdate=8 November 2017}}{{cite news|title=LORD DUFFERIN IS DEAD; Famous Diplomat's Last Days Were Clouded by Misfortune. He Never Wholly Recovered from the Shock of His Eldest Son's Death--The New Marquis Married Miss Flora Davis of This City|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1902/02/13/archives/lord-bufferin-is-bead-famous-diplomats-last-days-were-clouded-by.html|accessdate=8 November 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=13 February 1902}} ==Career== He was a clerk at the [[Foreign Office]], [[Diplomatic Service|Second Secretary of the Diplomatic Service]] and a [[Justice of the Peace]] and [[Deputy Lieutenant]] for [[County Down]].{{cite web|last1=Archives|first1=The National|title=Blackwood, Terence John Temple Hamilton-Temple- (1866-1918) 2nd Marquess of Dufferin and Ava|url=http://discovery.nationalarchives.gov.uk/details/c/F63348|website=discovery.nationalarchives.gov.uk|publisher=The Discovery Service|accessdate=8 November 2017}} ==Family== Lord Dufferin married Florence "Flora" Davis,{{cite book|last1=Chambliss|first1=William H.|title=Chambliss Diary: Or, Society as it Really is|date=1895|publisher=Chambliss|page=16|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OIcrAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA16&lpg=PA16|accessdate=8 November 2017|language=en}} a rich American singer who was the daughter of banker John H. Davis,{{cite news|title=LADY DUFFERIN IN CONCERT; Will Make Her Debut as a Public Singer in London on Dec. 15.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1910/12/04/archives/lady-dufferin-in-concert-will-make-her-debut-as-a-public-singer-in.html|accessdate=8 November 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=4 December 1910}} of 24 [[Washington Square Park|Washington Square]], [[New York City]],{{cite news|title=TO BE LADY BLACKWOOD.; EARL DUFFERIN'S SECOND SON TO WED MISS FLORA DAVIS OF NEW-YORK.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1892/11/19/archives/to-be-lady-blackwood-earl-dufferins-second-son-to-wed-miss-plora.html|accessdate=8 November 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=19 November 1892}}{{cite book|last1=MacColl|first1=Gail|last2=Wallace|first2=Carol|title=To Marry an English Lord|date=2012|publisher=Workman Publishing|isbn=9780761171959|page=379|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UGSE4B506MMC&pg=PA379&lpg=PA379|accessdate=8 November 2017|language=en}} in 1893.{{cite news|title=THE BLACKWOOD-DAVIS WEDDING.; The Religious Ceremony Celebrated Yesterday in Paris.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1893/10/17/archives/the-blackwooddavis-wedding-the-religious-ceremony-celebrated-yes.html|accessdate=8 November 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=17 October 1893}} Together, they were the parents of three daughters:{{cite web|title=Dufferin and Ava, Marquess of (UK, 1888 - 1988)|url=http://www.cracroftspeerage.co.uk/online/content/dufferin1888.htm|website=www.cracroftspeerage.co.uk|publisher=Heraldic Media Limited|accessdate=8 November 2017}} * Lady Doris Gwendoline Hamilton-Temple-Blackwood (1895–1984), who married Captain Cecil Bernard Gunston, [[Military Cross|MC]] (1885–1934) of the [[Coldstream Guards]], son of Major Bernard Gunston, formerly of the 5th [[Dragoon Guards]], on 19 October 1922. * Lady Ursula Florence Hamilton-Temple-Blackwood (b. 1899), who married Arthur Swithin Newton Horne, formerly of [[The King's Own Royal Border Regiment]] and Government Secretary of the [[Federated Malay States]] (d. 1954). * Lady Patricia Ethel Hamilton-Temple-Blackwood (1902–1983), who married [[Henry Russell (impresario)|Henry Russell]] (1871–1937), the former director of the [[Boston Opera Company]] and the son of musician [[Henry Russell (musician)|Henry Russell]], on 11 June 1926.{{cite news|title=LADY PATRICIA IS WED TO HENRY RUSSELL; Actress, Daughter of Countess Howe, Becomes Bride of Opera Impresario in Paris.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1926/06/12/archives/lady-patricia-is-wed-to-henry-russeil-actress-daughter-of-countess.html|accessdate=8 November 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=12 June 1926}} Lord Dufferin died from [[pneumonia]] on 7 February 1918 and was buried at the Dufferin ancestral seat of [[Clandeboye]], [[County Down]].{{cite news|title=MARQUIS OF DUFFERIN DIES. Diplomat's Widow Was Formerly Miss Florence Davis of New York|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1918/02/08/archives/obituary-3-no-title.html|accessdate=8 November 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=8 February 1918}} The [[marquessate]] passed to his youngest brother, Lord Frederick Blackwood.{{cite news|title=Obituary: Maureen, Marchioness of Dufferin and Ava|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/obituary-maureen-marchioness-of-dufferin-and-ava-1158254.html|accessdate=8 November 2017|work=[[The Independent]]|date=23 May 1998}} Two years after his death his widow married again, to [[Richard George Penn Curzon, 4th Earl Howe]], and died on 14 April 1925.{{cite web|title=Florence (née Davis), Marchioness of Dufferin and Ava (later Countess Howe) - Person - National Portrait Gallery|url=https://www.npg.org.uk/collections/search/person/mp98147/florence-nee-davis-marchioness-of-dufferin-and-ava-later-countess-howe|website=www.npg.org.uk|accessdate=8 November 2017|language=en}}{{cite news|title=LADY HOWE DIES' IN ENGLISH HOME; Former Flora H. Davis of New York a Victim of Heart Disease Following Influenza.|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9E02E5DE1138E233A25756C1A9629C946495D6CF&legacy=true|accessdate=8 November 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=15 April 1925}} ===Descendants=== Through his eldest daughter, he was the grandfather of Hermione Hamilton Gunston (b. 1923), who married Lt. Col. [[Walter Luttrell|Sir Walter Luttrell]] [[Military Cross|MC]], and Sonia Helen Gunston [[Justice of the Peace|JP]] (b. 1926), appointed Temporary [[Lady of the Bedchamber]] to [[Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom|Queen Elizabeth II]] in 1967, and who married [[Thomas Fairfax, 13th Lord Fairfax of Cameron]] (d.1964) and had issue including [[Nicholas Fairfax, 14th Lord Fairfax of Cameron]] (b. 1956). ==Arms== {{Infobox COA wide | image = | crest = 1st: On a Cap of Maintenance Gules turned up Ermine a Crescent Argent (Blackwood); 2nd, On a Ducal Coronet Or a Martlet Gold (Temple); 3rd, a Demi-Antelope affrontée Ermine attired and unguled Or holding between his hoofs a Heart Gules (Hamilton, Earl of Clanbrassill) | coronet = A [[Coronet|Coronet of an Marquess]] | escutcheon = Quarterly, 1st and 4th, Azure a Fess Or in chief a Crescent Argent between two Mullets of the second and in base a Mascle of the third (Blackwood); 2nd, quarterly, 1st and 4th, Or an Eagle displayed Sable, 2nd and 3rd, Argent two Bars Sable each charged with three Martlets Or (Temple); 3rd, Gules three Cinquefoils pierced Ermine on a Chief Or a Lion passant of the field (Hamilton, Earl of Clanbrassill) | supporters = Dexter: a Lion Gules armed and langued Azure gorged with a Tressure flory-counterflory Or; Sinister: an Heraldic Tiger Ermine gorged with a like Tressure Gules; each supporter supporting a Flag Staff proper therefrom flowing a Banner Or charged with a Peacock in his Pride also proper | motto = Per Vias Rectas (By straight ways) }} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.npg.org.uk/collections/search/person/mp103603/terence-john-temple-hamilton-temple-blackwood-2nd-marquess-of-dufferin-and-ava Photograph of the 2nd Marquess of Dufferin and Ava] [[photogravure]] by Walker & Boutall and by Gunn & Stuart {{S-start}} {{S-reg|uk}} {{Succession box | title=[[Marquess of Dufferin and Ava|Marquess of
Dufferin and Ava]] | before=[[Frederick Hamilton-Temple-Blackwood, 1st Marquess of Dufferin and Ava|Frederick Hamilton
Temple-Blackwood]] | after=[[Frederick Hamilton-Temple-Blackwood, 3rd Marquess of Dufferin and Ava|Frederick Hamilton
Temple-Blackwood]] | years=1902–1918 }} {{s-end}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2012}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dufferin And Ava, Terence Hamilton-Temple-Blackwood, 2nd Marquess of}} [[Category:1866 births]] [[Category:1918 deaths]] [[Category:British diplomats]] [[Category:Clerks]] [[Category:Blackwood family|Terence]] [[Category:Deputy Lieutenants of Down]] [[Category:Irish justices of the peace]] [[Category:Marquesses of Dufferin and Ava]]

revision.comment: Removing from [[Category:German composers]] (parent category) using [[c:Help:Cat-a-lot|Cat-a-lot]]
revision.text:
{{Redirect|Kempff|the Bolivian national park|Noel Kempff Mercado National Park}} {{More citations needed|date=January 2009}} [[Image:Wilhelm Kempff - Beethoven Piano Sonatas - DG 138 935.jpg|thumbnail|right|300px|Album cover for Wilhelm Kempff's recording of
[[Beethoven]] Piano Sonatas on [[#DG138935|DG 139 935]] (1965),
which received the [[Grand Prix du Disque]].]] '''Wilhelm Walter Friedrich Kempff''' (25 November 1895 – 23 May 1991) was a German pianist and composer. Although his repertoire included [[Johann Sebastian Bach|Bach]], [[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart|Mozart]], [[Frédéric Chopin|Chopin]], [[Robert Schumann|Schumann]], [[Franz Liszt|Liszt]] and [[Johannes Brahms|Brahms]], Kempff was particularly well known for his interpretations of the music of [[Ludwig van Beethoven]] and [[Franz Schubert]], recording the complete sonatas of both composers.{{cite news|title=Wilhelm Kempff Is Dead at 95|newspaper=The New York Times|date=25 May 1991|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/25/arts/wilhelm-kempff-is-dead-at-95-german-was-romantic-pianist.html|accessdate=9 May 2010}}Schubert, ''Complete Piano Sonatas'', 9-LP set Deutsche Grammophon 1976, one of a number of boxed sets issued under the title ''Hommage à Wilhelm Kempff'' to celebrate his fifty years of recording for the DG label. Booklets dedicated to both Schubert and Kempff. He is considered to have been one of the chief exponents of the Germanic tradition during the 20th century and one of the greatest pianists of all time.Kaiser, Joachim; Wooldridge, David, translator; Unwin, George, translator (1971). ''Great Pianists of Our Time''. New York: Herder and Herder. {{OCLC|235884}}. An entire chapter is devoted to Kempff. ==Early life== Kempff was born in [[Jüterbog]], [[Province of Brandenburg|Brandenburg]], in 1895. He grew up in nearby [[Potsdam]] where his father was a royal music director and organist at St. Nicolai Church. His grandfather was also an organist and his brother Georg became director of church music at the [[University of Erlangen]]. Kempff studied music at first at the Berlin Hochschule für Musik at the age of nine after receiving lessons from his father at a younger age. Whilst there he studied composition with [[Robert Kahn (composer)|Robert Kahn]] and piano with [[Karl Heinrich Barth]] (with whom [[Arthur Rubinstein]] also studied). In 1914 Kempff moved on to study at the Viktoria gymnasium in Potsdam before returning to Berlin to finish his training. ==As a pianist== In 1917, Kempff gave his first major recital, consisting of predominantly major works, including Beethoven's [[Piano Sonata No. 29 (Beethoven)|Hammerklavier Sonata]] and [[Johannes Brahms|Brahms]] [[Paganini Variations (Brahms)|Variations on a theme of Paganini]]. Kempff toured widely in Europe and much of the rest of the world. Between 1936 and 1979 he performed ten times in Japan (a small Japanese island was named ''Kenpu-san'' in his honor){{Citation needed|date=September 2010}}. Kempff made his first London appearance in 1951 and his first in New York in 1964. He gave his last public performance in Paris in 1981, and then retired for health reasons ([[Parkinson's Disease]]){{Citation needed|date=August 2014}}. He died in [[Positano]], Italy, in 1991 at the age of 95, five years after his wife, whom he had married in 1926. They were survived by seven children. Wilhelm Kempff recorded over a period of some sixty years. His recorded legacy includes works of [[Robert Schumann|Schumann]], Brahms, [[Franz Schubert|Schubert]], [[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart|Mozart]], [[Johann Sebastian Bach|Bach]], [[Franz Liszt|Liszt]], [[Frédéric Chopin|Chopin]] and particularly, of [[Ludwig van Beethoven|Beethoven]]. [[File:Ernest Ansermet and Wilhelm Kempff (1965) by Erling Mandelmann.jpg|thumb|Kempff (right) with [[Ernest Ansermet]] (left) in 1965]] He was the first to record the complete [[piano sonata|sonatas]] of Franz Schubert, long before these works became popular. (For Schubert sonatas which were left incomplete, Kempff recorded only the completed movements and not the fragments.) He also recorded two sets of the complete Beethoven sonatas (and one early, almost complete set on [[shellac]] (1926–1945), one in mono (1951–1956) and the other in stereo (1964–1965). He recorded the complete Beethoven [[piano concerto]]s twice as well, both with the [[Berlin Philharmonic]]; the first from the early 1950s in mono with [[Paul van Kempen]], and the later in stereo from the early 1960s with [[Ferdinand Leitner]]. Kempff also recorded [[chamber music]] with [[Yehudi Menuhin]], [[Pierre Fournier]], [[Wolfgang Schneiderhan (violinist)|Wolfgang Schneiderhan]], [[Paul Grummer]], and [[Henryk Szeryng]], among others. He left recordings of most of his repertory, including the complete sonatas of Beethoven and Schubert. He performed to an advanced age, continuing to give concerts past his eightieth birthday. His association with the Berlin Philharmonic spanned over sixty years. ===Technique and style=== As a performer Kempff stressed lyricism and spontaneity in music, particularly effective in intimate pieces or passages. He always strove for a singing, lyrical quality. He avoided extreme tempos and display for its own sake. The pianist [[Alfred Brendel]] has written that Kempff "played on impulse... it depended on whether the right breeze, as with an aeolian harp, was blowing. You then would take something home that you never heard elsewhere." (in Brendel's book, ''The Veil of Order''). He regards Kempff as the "most rhythmical" of his colleagues. Brendel helped choose the selections for Phillip's "Great Pianists of the 20th Century" issue of Kempff recordings, and wrote in the notes that Kempff "achieves things that are beyond him" in his "unsurpassable" recording of Liszt's first Legende, "St. Francis Preaching to the Birds." When pianist [[Artur Schnabel]] undertook his pioneering complete recording of the Beethoven sonatas in the 1930s, he told EMI that if he didn't complete the cycle, they should have Kempff complete the remainder – even though the two pianists took noticeably different approaches to the composer (for example, Schnabel preferred extremely fast or slow tempos, while Kempff preferred moderate ones). Later, when Kempff was in [[Finland]], the composer [[Jean Sibelius]] asked him to play the slow movement of Beethoven's 29th Sonata, the [[Piano Sonata No. 29 (Beethoven)|Hammerklavier]]; after Kempff finished, Sibelius told him, "You did not play that as a pianist but rather as a human being."Complete Beethoven Sonatas sleevenotes {{which}} ==As a teacher== From 1924 to 1929, Kempff took over the direction of the [[State University of Music and Performing Arts Stuttgart|Stuttgart College of Music]] as a successor of Max Pauer. In 1931, he was co-founder of the summer courses at Marmorpalais Potsdam. In 1957, Kempff founded Fondazione Orfeo (today: Kempff Kulturstiftung) in the south-Italian city [[Positano]] and held his first Beethoven interpretation masterclass at Casa Orfeo, which Kempff had built especially for this reason. He continued teaching there once a year until 1982. His wife died in 1986. After his death in 1991, [[Gerhard Oppitz]] taught the courses from 1992–1995, followed by [[John O'Conor|John O’Conor]] until 2011 and from 2013 onwards Bernd Goetzke. Oppitz and O'Conor had both been outstanding participants of Kempff's masterclasses and were personally closely connected with Wilhelm Kempff. Like his predecessors Bernd Goetzke is a former participant of the courses in Positano. Other noted pianists to have studied with Kempff include [[Jörg Demus]], [[Norman Shetler]], [[Mitsuko Uchida]], [[Peter Schmalfuss]], [[Idil Biret]] and [[Ventsislav Yankov]].''88 notes pour piano solo'', [[Jean-Pierre Thiollet]], Neva Ed., 2015, p. 340. {{ISBN|978 2 3505 5192 0}} ==Composition== A lesser-known activity of Kempff was composing. He composed for almost every genre and used his own cadenzas for Beethoven's Piano Concertos 1–4. His student [[Idil Biret]] has recorded a CD of his piano works. His second symphony premiered in 1929 at the [[Leipzig Gewandhaus Orchestra|Leipzig Gewandhaus]] by [[Wilhelm Furtwängler]]. He also prepared a number of Bach transcriptions, including the [[Siciliano]] from the [[Sonata in E-flat major for flute or recorder and harpsichord|Flute Sonata in E-flat major]], that have been recorded by Kempff and others. His opera ''Famile Gozzi'', a comic work in three acts, was written in 1934. ==Autobiography== * Kempff, Wilhelm. ''Unter dem Zimbelstern: Jugenderinnerungen eines Pianisten'' ["Under the Cymbal Star: The Development of a Musician" (1951)].
